relatedanime.anime: Asobi Asobase: Cosplay Taikai / Otona no Watashi e

recommendations.recommendation: It`s not quite Azumanga Daioh but it`s right up there. A real player in it`s genre. One of the better anime`s this season. If you like humorous, this is one you can`t miss out on.

From the subtle opening, which itself if a ploy hiding the shows intent, to each episode`s manic closing song, the jokes keep coming. Depending on your tastes, and occasionally your general anime knowledge, a few will be hit or miss. The constant shift in art styles to match the character`s moods was more than a deciding factor in my choosing to watch this. Then there is the expanding cast of secondary characters over time and later episodes playing off of earlier situations. I could easily point out that the third act of episode 8 was a favorite, but that might have more to do with taking a drink at clearly the wrong moment in time. If you are looking for shallow comedy that strives not to be pigeon-holed to an obvious trope this is my recommendation.

I came in expecting a light-hearted comedy but left with anxiety and a slight sense of horror. The show is indeed very funny, don`t get me wrong. Think of a NichiBros/Plastic Nee-san mash-up. 10/10 will watch again.
The best comedy of this year for me. Every single episode delivered some kind of comedy gold. And best ED on top of that. Highly recommended.
It`s so hilarious i cried laughing! Just Watch it if you like comedies.

anime.description: * Based on http://anidb.net/cr53462 [Suzukawa Rin]`s comedy seinen manga. The story revolves around three classmates who play simple hand games. http://anidb.net/ch94635 [One of the girls] is good at games, but hates them as she always lost to her older sister and forced to do chores while growing up. Another http://anidb.net/ch94633 [girl] is of American descent, but raised in Japan, and who only pretends to be bad at Japanese. Another http://anidb.net/ch94634 [girl] usually observes their games, and loses to the other girls. Source: ANN

tag.name: android
tag.description: An android is a robot or synthetic organism designed to look and act like a human.

tag.name: all-girls school
tag.description: This school is only for female students. There may be a few male teachers though.

tag.name: high school
tag.description: A secondary school that usually contains grades 10 through 12 in Japan, or 9 through 12 in America.

tag.name: robot
tag.description: A robot is an automatically guided machine, able to do tasks on its own. Another common characteristic is that by its appearance or movements, a robot often conveys a sense that it has intent or agency of its own. Not to be confused with android (human-like robot).

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: present
tag.description: Somewhere between past and future.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: absurdist humour
tag.description: Surreal humour, also known as absurdist humour, is a form of humour predicated on deliberate violations of causal reasoning, producing events and behaviours that are obviously illogical. Constructions of surreal humour tend to involve bizarre juxtapositions, non-sequiturs, irrational or absurd situations, and expressions of nonsense. The humour arises from a subversion of audience`s expectations, so that amusement is founded on unpredictability, separate from a logical analysis of the situation. Its appeal stems from the fact that the situation described is exceedingly ridiculous or unlikely. On an analytical level, all jokes contain a certain amount of incongruity, but while regular jokes carry an incongruity that the audience accepts as compatible with expectations, absurd jokes are characterized by a disproportionate amount of it, with the punch line delivering a situation incompatible with the world as we know it and failing to resolve the matter in the audience`s eyes. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: toilet humour
tag.description: Everything leads back to poo.

tag.name: school clubs
tag.description: Even though school clubs in Japan are not mandatory, there is some pressure from the social grid (e.g. fellow students, teachers) to participate in some kind of after-school activity, be it in sports or arts. Colleges also have clubs. As a comedy element in anime, some students have joined too many clubs, and are thus constantly stressed out. There is also the element of social commentary, making it clear that you have to join a club, if you want to be part of the class. Since self-founded clubs need at least 3 members, the desperate search and advertising for new members can be cause for hilarity in anime.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Japan is a sovereign island nation in East Asia. Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies off the eastern coast of the Asian mainland and stretches from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and China in the southwest. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: tennis
tag.description: Tennis is yet another sport involving hitting a ball. Were it not for the copious amounts of grass involved in certain varieties, it seems hard to imagine that people would pay it any attention at all.

tag.name: music
tag.description: Music anime generally revolves around people concerned with music in their everyday lives. In addition they often adhere to certain genre conventions, the emphasis on training and practice in preparation for competitions, characters desire for self improvement, and pursuit of a specific goal. This is not unlike the Sports category.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is Earth`s largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth`s total land area and 8.7% of the Earth`s total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: blackmail
tag.description: In general usage, blackmail is a crime involving unjustified threats against a person or organization in order to make a gain or harm or cause material loss to them unless a demand is met. It may be considered similar to or a form of extortion, although some jurisdictions will consider them as separate crimes. Most often, blackmail involves the threat of revealing some secret to a given third party, which may be another person, a rival organization, or a state institution such as the police, or to the general public. In anime and related media, and more specifically in pornographic works, blackmail is also a device used to coerce people, generally female and often schoolgirls, into having sex with another or others; in such cases, it may be considered similar to or a form of rape.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: friendship
tag.description: The feeling of trust, kindness, and friendship between a group of high school students for example, is a central theme of this anime.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: sports
tag.description: Sports anime revolves around a recreational physical activity or skill. In addition they often adhere to certain genre conventions, the emphasis on training and practice in preparation for competition, characters desire for self improvement, and pursuit of a specific goal.

tag.name: the arts
tag.description: The arts represent an outlet of human expression, usually influenced by culture, and driven by human creative impulse. Major constituents of the arts include literature – including poetry, novels and short stories, and epics; performing arts – among them music, dance, and theatre; culinary arts such as baking, chocolatiering, and winemaking; media arts like photography and film, and visual arts – including drawing, painting, and sculpting. Some art forms combine a visual element with performance (e.g. film) and the written word (e.g. comics). From prehistoric cave paintings to modern day films, art serves as a vessel for storytelling and conveying mankind`s relationship with its environment. Source: Wiki

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: funny expressions
tag.description: The facial expressions of the characters may change so quickly or unexpectedly distort that hilarity will ensue.

tag.name: wordplay
tag.description: The characters play with words. E.g. purposely or accidentally use similar-sounding but wrongly applied words in the Japanese original, leading to supposedly funny misunderstandings and confusion.

tag.name: character driven
tag.description: The main appeal of the show is the way the characters are portrayed and interact, focusing on dialogue, spending time together or getting to know each other. These anime are not "story-less" but story is secondary to character development and the characters themselves and what they experience.

tag.name: competition
tag.description: Some sort of confrontation occurs in this show. The protagonists "duke it out" via various competitions.

tag.name: dialogue driven
tag.description: A dialogue driven show has its story advanced by dialogue, with action being of much lower priority, and relies heavily on conversations between characters.

tag.name: facial distortion
tag.description: The characters face are exaggerated into a misshape, deformed, and almost warped. Used as comedy element to express extreme mood swings. Differing from "http://anidb.net/t2652 [Super Deformed]", here only the face changes to an extreme degree, not the whole body of the protagonist.

tag.name: cultural references
tag.description: The plot of this anime shows signs of cultural references, these are often jokes that make reference to a certain custom, habit or history that is specifically attributed to that culture. Knowledge of the culture itself is needed in order to properly understand these jokes.

tag.name: OP and ED sung by characters
tag.description: OP and/or ED in this anime is sung by the characters and animation shows them singing.

tag.name: ensemble cast
tag.description:
A show with an ensemble cast focuses on a larger group of main characters in a single plot narrative; anime containing several segmented plot narratives (such as episodic or arc-based plots) are excluded. As such, it doesn`t really have a "main" or "lead" character; instead, every member of the central main character group plays an important part in the show`s grander scheme; no single character is more important or prominent than the others (equality of importance). Further, subplots (if any) lead by each character in the ensemble have equal weighting in importance (or lack of weight).
* In a show where no single main character is more important or prominent than the others, 4+ main characters is almost always an ensemble cast. * A show with 3 main characters of equal importance is likely also an ensemble cast; equality of importance must be considered carefully. * A show with 2 main characters of equal importance is generally not an ensemble cast situation; however, on an exception basis where neither main character is considered an antagonist, a 2-main-character anime may be considered an ensemble (e.g. http://anidb.net/a11829 [Kimi no Na wa.]).
Pictured: http://anidb.net/a9043 [K (anime)]

tag.name: predominantly female cast
tag.description: A show with a predominantly female cast has mostly females as main and secondary cast members while few if any male characters have major roles. This also applies when a male lead is surrounded by females of lesser individual plot relevance, such as in a harem setting.

tag.name: tone changes
tag.description: The anime switches quickly, often rather drastically between different moods or tones, sometimes even on the same scene.

tag.name: heavy metal music
tag.description: Heavy metal (or simply metal) is a genre of rock music that developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, largely in the United Kingdom and the United States. With roots in blues rock and psychedelic rock, the bands that created heavy metal developed a thick, massive sound, characterized by highly amplified distortion, extended guitar solos, emphatic beats, and overall loudness. Heavy metal lyrics and performance styles are often associated with masculinity, aggression, and machismo. Heavy metal is traditionally characterized by loud distorted guitars, emphatic rhythms, dense bass-and-drum sound, and vigorous vocals. Metal subgenres variously emphasize, alter, or omit one or more of these attributes. The anime features a theme revolving around metal music or generally features metal music.

tag.name: penis jokes
tag.description: A penis or other phallic object is used as a device to elicit laughter from the viewer. This also includes indirect references to such objects provided the intent is clearly the same.

tag.name: flat chest jokes
tag.description: Jokes about the (supposedly or actually) flat chest of a character.

tag.name: randomness
tag.description: The anime does not follow a predictable storyline. New, strange, obscure, or otherwise unexpected story elements are introduced at a whim.

tag.name: mundane made awesome
tag.description: Sometimes normal just doesn`t cut it. Eating: you put food in your month and chew. Playing sports: you throw a ball around. You need to make it awesome, no matter how mundane it is. Let`s throw in some gripping orchestral music, lighting changes, different camera angles, something! Don`t write like a man, write like an evil overlord! Exaggerate your expressions and gestures, speak with excessive intonation, and if all else fails, throw in some close-ups, slow motion, and ominous Latin chanting! With practice, even you can turn something like eating chips into an epic battle of light and dark, blinding the viewer with sheer awesomeness. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: Engrish
tag.description: Engrish is actually a mispronunciation of English, as can be the result of someone, who does not have English as their primary language of origin (such as Japanese or Chinese). Occasionally characters in the original Japanese dialogue version of an anime will speak in English... however; this often still requires the assistance of subtitles, for while the words are meant to be said in English, the sentence structure and letter pronunciation may still be strongly related to the person’s primary language.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: multi-segment episodes
tag.description: Multi-segment episodes are split into several short segments (parts), usually with separate titles and independent storylines. Not to be confused with http://anidb.net/t5852 [short episodes], which are regular episodes that are much shorter than the standard length (up to and including 10 minutes). Also not to be confused with an OVA or music video with multiple (otherwise unrelated) full-length http://anidb.net/t7241 [bundled episodes] consolidated into a single episode video track.

tag.name: episodic
tag.description: An episodic anime consists of many successive short arcs that are generally 1-2 episodes in length, with strong plot continuity within each arc but generally little continuity from one arc to the next. For long shows (well upwards of 50 episodes), the episode count constraint is less tight; for example, a show with close to 250 episodes would also be considered episodic if it consisted of a majority of arcs of up to 3 or maybe 4 episodes and possibly also very few slightly longer arcs.

tag.name: misleading beginning
tag.description: The beginning of the show is misleading as to the tone, premise, or story path that the rest of the story will take. Sometimes, it even follows an entirely different cast that never appears again. This may take the form of the first episode or couple of episodes of a series or the first few minutes of e.g. a movie.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: sexual humour
tag.description: Sexual humour is prevalent in this anime. It often involves cheeky or crude sexual language, with innuendos and jokes about the female or male genitalia. Often, such anime also have http://anidb.net/t2856 [ecchi] elements to them.

character.name: Olivia
character.description: Olivia is http://anidb.net/ch94634 [Hanako]`s and http://anidb.net/ch94635 [Kasumi]`s classmate who feigns her foreign ethnicity by pretending to be an American transfer student despite having only been born and raised in Japan with foreign parents. Thus, she pretends to speak in broken Japanese to keep her image while gradually getting better to solidify her act. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Honda Hanako
character.description: Hanako is http://anidb.net/ch94633 [Olivia]`s and http://anidb.net/ch94635 [Kasumi]`s classmate who is extremely energetic, dragging both of them into her pace by playing strange games at school. Her family is shown to have some of wealthy or noble connection as she is able to obtain objects upon request. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Nomura Kasumi
character.description: Kasumi is http://anidb.net/ch94633 [Olivia]`s and http://anidb.net/ch94634 [Hanako]`s classmate who dislikes playing games due to her sister`s constant teasing when she was younger. She is very bad at English despite looking like a library girl. She enjoys writing BL fantasies. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Matou Aguri
character.description: Matou Aguri, nicknamed Agrippa, is http://anidb.net/ch95389 [Oka]`s fellow member in the Occult Research Club. She was temporarily out of school for medical reasons. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Maeda
character.description: Maeda is http://anidb.net/ch94634 [Hanako]`s family butler. Due to being probed by aliens, he is capable of firing laser beams out of his butt. He can quickly build or procure any item that Hanako asks for, from an inflatable kiddie pool to a robot that speaks in pre-programmed English phrases. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Oka-san
character.description: Oka is the leader of the Occult Research Club who befriends the http://anidb.net/ch98335 [Pastimers Club], teaching them occult-themed games. Her nickname is Luu. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Higuchi Chisato
character.description: Higuchi Chisato is a teacher who is blackmailed into becoming the advisor for the Pastimers` Club, who often feels downhearted over not being able to find a boyfriend. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Seitokaichou
character.description: Student Council President is a smart, bespectacled girl whose real name has not been revealed. Despite her timid demeanor, she managed to win her position with a speech that sounded threatening to the rest of the student body. She constantly throws up procedural barriers for the Pastimers Club, and wavers between trying to be friends with them or undermining their club. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Aozora Tsugumi
character.description: Tsugumi is a feminine-presenting classmate who the http://anidb.net/ch98335 [Pastimers] suspect of actually being male, leading them to go to great lengths to uncover Tsugumi`s true identity. Tsugumi keeps their identity ambiguous and enjoys teasing the club in return.

character.name: Takayanagi-sensei
character.description: Ms. Takayanagi is the school guidance councilor who is rather manly in appearance. She has an equally-manly younger sister in her third year who is president of the Swimming Club. Source: Wikipedia

episode.title: 下半身からビーム / 目クソ鼻クソ / 不法占拠 / 尻遊び
Lower Body Lasers / Pots and Kettles / Illegal Occupation / Butt Play
Lasers sous la ceinture / L`Hôpital qui se moque de la charité / Occupation illégale / Jeu de boule
Kahanshin kara Beam / Mekuso Hanakuso / Fuhou Senkyo / Shiri Asobi
episode.summary: Maeda-san, who works at Hanako’s home, fires lasers from his butt. This offers Kasumi with a unique perspective for her fan fiction. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 絶対に負けられない戦い / 操り人形 / 命懸け
A Battle That Must Be Won / Puppets / Betting My Life
Défaite interdite / Marionnette / Au péril de sa vie
Zettai ni Makerarenai Tatakai / Ayatsuri Ningyou / Inochigake
episode.summary: Kasumi isn’t amused at the stakes involved in the game that Hanako and Olivia are playing. Her well-meant intention to make the game more wholesome backfires. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 暇つぶし / 友情ゲーム / 魔女裁判 / ノンタイトルマッチ
Killing Time / Friendship Game / The Witch Trials / Non-title Match
Passe-temps / Le jeu de l`amitié / Procès en sorcellerie / Rencontre amicale
Himatsubushi / Yuujou Game / Majo Saiban / Non-title Match
episode.summary: The Pastimers don’t have the minimum number of members necessary to be officially recognized as a club. They attempt to negotiate with the student council president, who isn’t impressed by the club’s activities. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 等価交換 / チープなスリル / 遊び人 / 優しい変態
Equivalent Exchange / Cheap Thrills / Pleasure Seekers / The Kind Pervert
Échange de bons procédés / Cheap thrill / Les joueuses / Gentil pervers
Toukakoukan / Cheap na Thrill / Asobinin / Yasashii Hentai
episode.summary: livia has an odd way of playing look-the-other-way. Her opponent, Hanako, convinces Kasumi to play against her instead. This is the beginning of the Pastimers Club. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: Ending
Opening
バイキン, ゲットだぜ! / 神の啓示 / 魔のスゴロク
Gotta "Catch" `em All! / Divine Revelation / The Evil Sugoroku
Germes, attrapez-les tous ! / Révélation divine / Jeu de l`oie démoniaque
Baikin, Get Daze! / Kami no Keiji / Ma no Sugoroku
episode.summary: When Hanako sees Olivia wandering around the classroom with her face glued to her smartphone, she assumes she’s playing that popular monster-collecting game, but it turns out that she’s playing an unfamiliar game called Bactéri GO. Olivia explains that the objective of the game is to collect the many kinds of bacteria that populate the area, and that it was developed in her parents’ country. She describes the game in detail to Hanako, but… Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 怪盗・あそ研 / 恐怖の女 / 電波でGO / おっぱいの悲劇
Phantom Thieves: Pass Club / Woman of Terror / Weirdo Go / Boobie Tragedy
Le cercle des voleurs / Filles éffroyables / Bizarre, vous avez dis bizarre ? / Crime de lèse-poitrine
Kaitou Aso Ken / Kyoufu no Onna / Denpa de Go / Oppai no Higeki
episode.summary: Hanako, Olivia, and Kasumi are asked by Aozora Tsugumi to go into the student council room to retrieve the Banana Papers that are hidden somewhere in there. The Banana Papers contain scandals that have happened around school and the student council president is apparently using that to blackmail other students. Hanako and the other girls try to decline the request, but Tsugumi manages to buy them all off one way or another and they end up having to go get the Banana Papers... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アスタリスク / テスト勉強 / イメチェン / 激闘, 再び
Asterisk / Studying for Exams / A New Look / Spirited Combat, Again
Astérisque / Révisions / Changement de look / Combat acharné, le retour
Asterisk / Test Benkyou / Ima Chan / Gekitou, Futatabi
episode.summary: Hanako and the other girls are asked by Oka-san from the Occult Research Club if they want to read a grimoire with her. They ask Oka-san how gathering members is going for the club and she tells them that she hasn’t been able to find anyone since. Apparently the reason she ended up on her own suddenly is two had graduated, one had transferred and another one teleported. After hearing that, Hanako and the others didn’t know what to do... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 悪魔的センス / 誘導尋問 / 前多の呪い / 性教育
Devilish Taste / Loaded Questions / Maeda`s Curse / Sex Ed
Style d`enfer / Interrogatoire orienté / La malédiction de Maeda / Éducation sexuelle
Akumateki Sense / Yuudoujinmon / Maeda no Noroi / Seikyouiku
episode.summary: Hanako arrives at a café to meet up with Olivia and Kasumi. Olivia and Kasumi were just commenting on how this is the first time they’ve seen each other out of their school uniforms and when they see Hanako, they are shocked. Olivia asks Hanako if she hit her head on the way there, but Hanako tells them that her clothes were a very special kind of haute couture. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ダニエル / ブラ会議 / メルヘン・バトルロワイヤル / 紙のみぞ戦争
Daniel / Bra Meeting / Fairy Tale Battle Royale / Paper Wars
Daniel / Réunion des gros bonnets / Battle royale au pays des merveilles / Guerre sur papier
Daniel / Bra Kaigi / Marchen Battle Royal / Kami no Mizo Sensou
episode.summary: The trio is left to take care of a baby. The baby tries to take care of the trio. Hanako is struck down by the boob gods. Olivia takes Hanako and Kasumi to Fairy Tale Hell. They play a game that never ends. It just goes on and on, my friends. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: さよなら生徒会長 / オカケン・ウィッチ・プロジェクト / 顔面凶器
Goodbye, Student Council President / Oka-ken Witch Project / Face of Mass Destruction
Au revoir, présidente / Projet sorcière du club occulte / Visage létal
Sayonara Seitokaichou / Okaken Witch Project / Ganmen Kyouki
episode.summary: The three visit the student council president to demand that their film be accepted for the cultural festival. The president, meanwhile, is busy trying to get the vice president to let her visit the boys school across the street. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 心がぴょんぴょん / 華子のハレンチ裁判 / ティンPOの秘密 / 映画制作
Heart Go Boing Boing / Hanako`s Trial of Shame / Secret of the Dong / Film Production
Mon cœur bat très fort / Le procès impudique de Hanako / Le secret m`habite / Tournage de film
Kokoro ga Pyonpyon / Hanako no Harenchi Saiban / Tinpo no Himitsu / Eiga Seisaku
episode.summary: Because of her appearance, Fujiwara-san is assumed to be good at classical literature, even though her talent is in English, having replaced Olivia in the English speech contest and won. She`s exasperated by all of her classmates who come to her to ask for help with classical literature during break time, and she comes to Olivia for someone to speak in English with. Olivia becomes fearful, suspecting that Fujiwara-san has figured out that she can`t speak English.. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: エセ外国人の悩み / ダッチなワイフ / 遺伝子操作
Troubles of a Fake Foreigner / A Dutchey Wife / Genetic Engineering
Tracas d`une fausse étrangère / Poupée gonflée / Manipulation génétique
Ese Gaikokujin no Nayami / Dutch na Wife / Idenshisousa
episode.summary: Olivia’s classmates try to strike a conversation with her during the break after English class. She hadn’t talked to them much until then, even though their seats are nearby, but thanks to Hanako and Kasumi, who don’t speak to her much in class, her classmates are still under the impression that she’s fluent in English. Olivia begs Hanako to talk to her more in class so she can fix the misconception that she’s good at English, but… Source: crunchyroll
